author: By Henry Goldblatt
title: A Brief History of ‘Karen’
description: In 1965, it was the third-most-popular baby name in the United States. In 2018, it was the 635th — and today it’s even less popular. How did Karens fall so far?
content: Ask a woman named Karen what she used to think of her name and you’ll hear phrases like “generic,” “perfectly serviceable” and “an easy name.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan O'Grady
title: How Should I Respond to Overzealous Gestures of Sympathy?
description: “These people mire you in your sense of loss just as you are ready to discover what remains to be found,” writes one of our advice columnists.
content: In T’s advice column, Culture Therapist, either Ligaya Mishan or Megan O’Grady solves your problems using art. Have a question? Need some comfort? Email us at advice@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: In Ultra-Wealthy Greenwich, Teen Parties Lead to Jump in Virus Cases
description: Many of those exposed were seniors who had just finished their final year at two elite private schools.
content: On a warm summer weekday in the middle of July in Greenwich, Conn., one of the wealthiest communities in the country, a group of teenagers gathered at a house party. Many were seniors who had just finished their final year at two elite private college-preparatory schools, Greenwich Academy and the Brunswick School, as well as the local public high school, Greenwich High School, according to accounts from students and school officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: An Artist Having Fun While Waiting for Catastrophe
description: Heather Phillipson’s works make viewers smile, but underneath their bright, over-the-top exteriors are dark, urgent messages.
content: LONDON — The artist Heather Phillipson’s latest work is a 31-foot statue of a dollop of whipped cream, with a fly on it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew M. Cuomo
title: Let’s End the Wait for Coronavirus Test Results. Here’s How.
description: States should look to New York’s strategies.
content: It’s been six months since the United States reported its first coronavirus case, and getting a test can still take days. National labs are overwhelmed, leaving people to wait as much as two weeks for results. Every day that testing falls short is another day the virus can spread undetected, costing lives and delaying the reopening of our economy, schools and society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: ‘The Better I Got in Sports, the Worse the Racism Got’
description: Patty Mills, a key reserve for the San Antonio Spurs, said he developed an emotional shield from a lifetime of racial abuse, but he is using the platform of the N.B.A.’s restart to speak out against racism.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — There were a few must-pack accessories for Patty Mills of the San Antonio Spurs for his stay at Walt Disney World. Mills brought a stack of books on Black history in the United States and his native Australia. He made sure to carefully transport his favorite flat-brimmed hat, which bears two flags representing Australia’s Indigenous populations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cathleen D. Cahill and Sarah Deer
title: In 1920, Native Women Sought the Vote. Here’s What They Seek Now.
description: The 19th Amendment did not bring the right to vote to all Native women, but two experts in a conversation said it did usher in the possibility of change.
content: Native women were highly visible in early 20th-century suffrage activism. White suffragists, fascinated by Native matriarchal power, invited Native women to speak at conferences, join parades, and write for their publications. Native suffragists took advantage of these opportunities to speak about pressing issues in their communities — Native voting, land loss and treaty rights. But their stories have largely been forgotten.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: ‘Hey, You Free on Friday for a Meeting and a Bank Heist?’
description: Eager for an alternative to Zoom, executives are getting together in video games, to bond, brainstorm or rampage.
content: The ask-nice approach had not worked. Lewis Smithingham, an advertising executive in Brooklyn, was trying to land a virtual meeting with an analyst at an investment management firm, who he hoped would be both a source of potential clients and information. Dates were agreed to and then postponed, rescheduled and rescheduled again. So Mr. Smithingham had an idea. He would end the brush-offs by emailing a cheeky invitation:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
title: Trump Officials Reconsider Prosecuting ISIS ‘Beatles’ Without Death Penalty
description: American military officials in Iraq want two detainees taken off their hands and a British court has blocked sharing evidence for any death-penalty case. But other options are also getting a second look.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is trying again to find a way to resolve the cases of two British Islamic State detainees who are notorious for their roles in the torture and killing of Western hostages, and who have been held in indefinite wartime detention by the American military in Iraq since October, according to officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: How Andy Samberg and Cristin Milioti Meet Cute in ‘Palm Springs’
description: The director Max Barbakow narrates a wedding sequence from his comedy, now streaming on Hulu.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Dobby Dobson, Versatile Jamaican Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 78
description: Best known for his hit “I’m a Loving Pauper,” he was a significant figure in the evolution of Jamaican music. He died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: The Less Impossible Israeli-Palestinian Peace
description: The two-state idea is comatose but not dead.
content: Let’s play the Israel-Palestine impossibility game. It’s timely because the two-state peace for which I have long argued is now widely deemed unattainable. The answer, as one of the most thoughtful observers of the conflict, Peter Beinart, has recently argued, must be one state with equal rights for Jews and Palestinians, “a Jewish home that is not a Jewish state.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix, Amazon and More in August
description: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are our picks for August.
content: For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Farrell
title: In a 19th-Century Cart House, a Designer Creates a Room of Her Own
description: Harriet Anstruther has transformed a former outbuilding on her farm in the British countryside into a maximalist retreat.
content: When the British designer Harriet Anstruther first moved into the 500-year-old wattle-and-daub West Sussex farmhouse she shares with her husband, the photographer Henry Bourne, in 1998, there wasn’t much of a garden. “It was a nest of brambles and snakes,” she recalls of the square half-acre walled plot that separates the timber-frame home from the property’s roughly 100 acres of pasture, woodland and wildflower meadows. “It was cold and wet,” she says, “but unbelievably idyllic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘This Land Is Our Land’ and ‘Your House Will Pay’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: WE ARE THE WEATHER: Saving the Planet Begins at Breakfast, by Jonathan Safran Foer. (Picador, 288 pp., $18.) The central argument of this “eye-opening” essay collection of “Foer’s thoughts about life and crisis,” as our reviewer, Mark Bittman, described it, is that the very least we can do to reduce our carbon footprint is refrain from eating animal products except in the evening.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 31, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, July 31, 2020.
content: An article on Thursday about Representative Louie Gohmert of Texas testing positive for the coronavirus misidentified the state that Raúl M. Grijalva represents. It is Arizona, not New Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Covid-19 Tests Are in Short Supply. Should You Still Get One?
description: Public health officials once suggested only people with symptoms should be tested. Now some say getting one is a civic duty.
content: First, health officials said you should not get tested for the coronavirus unless you had symptoms. Then the message shifted: Mass testing was essential to trace and contain the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: More Than Just a Tweet: Trump’s Campaign to Undercut Democracy
description: Floating the idea of delaying the election was the latest step in the president’s running effort to discredit the election, risking long-term damage to public trust in the system.
content: Nothing in the Constitution gives President Trump the power to delay the November election, and even fellow Republicans dismissed it out of hand when he broached it on Thursday. But that was not the point. With a possible defeat looming, the point was to tell Americans that they should not trust their own democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: John Lewis Was the Anti-Trump
description: The president doesn’t seem to know what democracy is; the congressman embodied it.
content: In his final essay, published on Thursday in The New York Times, Representative John Lewis of Georgia offered welcome words of encouragement and wisdom for everyone protesting discrimination and injustice. He also made a crucial point about our political system, one that bears repeating as we face powerful threats to self-government and the rule of law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: Wrong Places at the Right Time
description: The Rev. Lydia Wittman and Rafi Ziauddin nearly missed their first chance to connect, but found so many more chances later.
content: If there hadn’t been two Dunkin’ stores on the same road in East Hartford, Conn., then maybe the Rev. Lydia Wittman and Rafi Ziauddin wouldn’t have ended up at different doughnut shops for their first date in 2014. And they wouldn’t have missed the beginning of the University of Connecticut football game or the tailgate party they meant to attend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Outdoors Innovation
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: If you’re looking for a pick-me-up — to be inspired by human ingenuity in the midst of a whole lot of bad news — today’s newsletter is for you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Katie Glueck
title: Republicans and White House at Odds Over Kansas Senate Race
description: Some in the G.O.P. want President Trump to endorse the opponent of Kris Kobach, who they worry could cost them a traditionally safe Senate seat. So far, the White House has declined to do so.
content: WASHINGTON — As the Kansas Senate primary barrels to a close, tensions are rising between Senate Republicans and the White House over the potential nomination of Kris Kobach, who party officials fear would jeopardize the seat and further imperil their Senate majority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: San Francisco 49ers Look to Increase Stake in Leeds United
description: The N.F.L. team, which has owned a piece of the soccer team since 2018, is in talks to increase its investment now that Leeds is returning to the Premier League.
content: LONDON — It took the San Francisco 49ers seven years to turn their interest in owning a piece of an English soccer team into reality. Now, two years after buying a 10 percent stake in Leeds United, the 49ers’ owners are looking to increase their investment, and their involvement, in the storied club that two weeks ago won promotion to the Premier League.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: St. Louis Cardinals Postpone Game After Two Players Test Positive for Virus
description: Baseball’s outbreak spreads to a third major league clubhouse, but Major League Baseball said the Cardinals’ game on Saturday will go ahead as planned.
content: Major League Baseball’s worrying coronavirus outbreak spread into another clubhouse on Friday when the St. Louis Cardinals’ game in Milwaukee was postponed after two Cardinals players tested positive for the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman, Liz Alderman and Jack Ewing
title: Despite Historic Plunge, Europe’s Economy Flashes Signs of Recovery
description: European countries that have better contained the virus are poised for speedier economic recovery than the United States.
content: LONDON — Before the pandemic, a traditional state of play prevailed in the enormous economies on the opposite sides of the Atlantic. Europe — full of older people, and rife with bickering over policy — appeared stagnant. The United States, ruled by innovation and risk-taking, seemed set to grow faster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Italian Fashion Hasn’t Changed Enough, Black Designers Say
description: A new letter sent by independent designers to fashion executives demands reform, or at least a serious conversation about race.
content: The designer Stella Jean wanted to make something clear about an impassioned letter she sent to Italian fashion’s governing body: “It’s not a protest,” she said. “I’m not protesting. It’s a proposal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Marcus Payadue
title: Testing, TikTok, Beyoncé: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: The Romans Called it ‘Alexandrian Glass.’ Where Was It Really From?
description: Trace quantities of isotopes hint at the true origin of a kind of glass that was highly prized in the Roman Empire.
content: Glass was highly valued across the Roman Empire, particularly a colorless, transparent version that resembled rock crystal. But the source of this coveted material — known as Alexandrian glass — has long remained a mystery. Now, by studying trace quantities of the element hafnium within the glass, researchers have shown that this prized commodity really did originate in ancient Egypt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Chewy Meets Crispy in This Summery Salad
description: This satisfying bowl gets its bite from farro, its crunch from spiced chickpeas, and its sweetness from roasted corn and slivered fennel.
content: Farro salads have a lot going on in the texture department. Unlike their softer sisters — quinoa, couscous and rice — farro has a hearty, starchy chewiness that’s satisfying even before you start tossing in piles of diced vegetables, dried fruit and toasted nuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Lets Trump Keep Building His Border Wall
description: The court refused to lift a year-old stay notwithstanding an appeals court ruling that the construction was unlawful.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday rejected a request from environmental groups to stop construction of President Trump’s border wall while the administration seeks review of an appeals court loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: This Week, Clean Your Stove
description: Some straightforward advice for a reader who feels directionless
content: Welcome. We started At Home to help readers lead a full and cultured life during the pandemic, featuring great reads and helpful advice alongside recommendations for things to do and watch and listen to and see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dambisa Moyo
title: 3 Things to Make the World Immediately Better After Covid-19
description: The crisis could be a catalyst for overhauling the economic world order.
content: The scale of the coronavirus pandemic and the economic shutdowns it caused set in motion a series of debates and questions about what the world may look like once its stranglehold on society loosens: Will we travel less? Will we work at home more? Will norms in schools and at large-scale public events be changed for years?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Edmund Lee
title: James Murdoch Resigns From News Corp, Ending Role in Family Empire
description: While his elder brother, Lachlan Murdoch, rises in the family business, James Murdoch has grown more distant from his father’s companies.
content: James Murdoch wants the world to know he is out of the family business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: White House and Congress Clash on Relief Plan as Jobless Aid Expires
description: President Trump and Democrats blamed each other for the lapse of $600-per-week federal unemployment benefits, risking further economic pain and a voter backlash for failing to act.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House and Congress hurtled over an economic and political cliff on Friday, failing to reach agreement to extend $600-per-week federal jobless aid payments for millions of Americans before their midnight expiration and risking a backlash from voters amid a pandemic-induced recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bethany Groff Dorau
title: Spending My Tenderness on Animals
description: As a vulnerable girl at a remote commune, I sought solace from horses, goats, even a bear cub. Today’s dark times have sent me their way again.
content: When it all went to hell, we adopted sheep.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kamala Harris Pushes Back on Criticism of ‘Ambition’
description: President Trump warned of an “election disaster” with mail-in voting, but cited no evidence of fraud. Joe Biden has postponed his planned announcement of a running mate.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the 2020 Election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Does Trump Want to Save His Economy?
description: The president is showing little urgency or strategy as the economic recovery stalls ahead of the November election.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States just suffered its worst economic quarter in nearly 75 years. Its recovery from the depths of a pandemic-induced recession has stalled, as coronavirus deaths rise again across the country. President Trump has what appears to be one final chance to cut a deal with Congress to ensure hard-hit workers and businesses do not collapse before the November election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: The Lynn Shelton That Marc Maron Knew
description: The comedian and podcaster reflects on his relationship with the filmmaker and TV director who died unexpectedly in May.
content: When the writer-director Lynn Shelton died in May, it was a devastating loss to film, to moviegoers who knew her for intimate low-budget features like “Humpday” and “Your Sister’s Sister,” and to TV audiences starting to discover her work as a director on series like “GLOW” and “The Morning Show.” On Tuesday, she received a posthumous Emmy directing nomination for the Hulu limited series “Little Fires Everywhere.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Treuer
title: A Native American Coming-of-Age and the Uses of Enchantment
description: In James Bird’s “The Brave,” a boy bullied for his numeric mind undergoes a metamorphosis when he’s sent to live on a reservation with his Native American mother.
content: James Bird’s THE BRAVE (Feiwel and Friends, 320 pp., $16.99; ages 9 to 12) is a bighearted book about Collin. Collin has a few problems. The most pressing is his compulsion to blurt out the number of letters in the words spoken to him. This leads to bullying and misunderstandings, and turns a sweet, smart adolescent into a problem child. When the novel opens, Collin has caused one problem too many for his beleaguered father, who sends him to live with his Ojibwe mother (whom he’s never met) on a reservation in Minnesota.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: How 2 New York Schools Became Models for Coping in a Pandemic
description: Vulnerable children need creative solutions, educators say: “The entire system has missed something if they don’t rethink what the fall semester looks like.”
content: Around 3 a.m. one day this past spring, a math teacher at Mott Haven Academy was stirred awake by the buzz of a text message. It was from a student, who wrote that his mother had just died from the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Drucker and Ellen Gabler
title: Kodak C.E.O. Got Stock Options Day Before News of Loan Sent Stock Soaring
description: The stock options suddenly were worth about $50 million — the latest instance of extraordinary good timing by corporate executives.
content: At the beginning of this week, the Eastman Kodak Company handed its chief executive 1.75 million stock options.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Raven Leilani, a Flâneur Who Is Going Places
description: The novelist’s debut, “Luster,” is winning accolades for its unfiltered depiction of sex, failure and a Black woman adrift in work and life.
content: Raven Leilani has one of this summer’s most anticipated fiction debuts, but in some ways, she is already anticipating the day the buzz dies down.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Catch up: Ford posts a profit, United warns pilots of furloughs and more.
description: Here’s some of what happened on Thursday that you might have missed.
content: Here’s some of what happened on Thursday that you might have missed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Low-Key Cooking
description: These recipes are simple and satisfying enough for those sweet and drowsy August days.
content: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. Somehow, we have arrived at July 31, the month gone in a flash. Let’s keep things low-key this week: That sweet and drowsy August feeling is about to set in. Ideas? Thoughts? You can find me at dearemily@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Ellen DeGeneres Apologizes to Staff Members as WarnerMedia Investigates Show
description: The longtime host acknowledged that her talk show’s workplace was not “a place of happiness” and vowed to take a more hands-on role.
content: Ellen DeGeneres apologized to the staff members of her talk show in an email on Thursday, a week after Warner Bros. Television informed employees that its parent company would conduct an investigation into the program’s troubled workplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: 7 Killed as Two Planes Crash in Alaska, Officials Say
description: Gary Knopp, a Republican member of the State House of Representatives, was among those killed. He was piloting one of the planes.
content: Seven people were killed, including a member of the Alaska State Legislature, after two planes collided in midair on Friday morning in the Alaskan city of Soldotna, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A $600-a-Week Lifeline for Unemployed Americans Expires After an Impasse in Washington
description: California became the first state to reach 500,000 total coronavirus cases. Once the site of a major outbreak, Italy now offers lessons for keeping the virus in check.
content: A $600 weekly jobless benefit from the federal government that became a lifeline for tens of millions of unemployed Americans, while also helping prop up the coronavirus-ravaged economy, expired at midnight as officials in Washington failed to agree on a new relief bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Malik B., Longtime Member of the Roots, Is Dead at 47
description: He brought his understatedly gritty lyrics and cadence to the band during its formative years. After he went solo, he dropped in on a few Roots albums.
content: Malik B., the elusive M.C. best known for his work with the Roots, died on Wednesday. He was 47.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Tae McDermott
title: How Massage Therapists in California Are Adapting to the Pandemic
description: Some counties in California have not allowed personal care businesses to reopen. Other counties have moved them exclusively outdoors.
content: Good morning. You cannot give a massage over Zoom. And that means California’s decisions to declare many massage therapists as nonessential workers has made their lives especially challenging in the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac, Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport
title: Microsoft Said to Be in Talks to Buy TikTok, as Trump Weighs Curtailing App
description: The discussions come as TikTok’s ownership by a Chinese company is under scrutiny by the White House and lawmakers.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — TikTok, the Chinese-owned video app that has been under scrutiny from the Trump administration, is in talks to sell itself to Microsoft and other companies as President Trump weighs harsh actions against the business, including forcing TikTok to divorce itself from its parent company, ByteDance, said people with knowledge of the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Antonio Brown Suspended Eight Games by the N.F.L.
description: The All-Pro receiver was penalized for his role in a January dispute at his home and for sending threatening tests to a woman who had accused him of sexual misconduct.
content: The N.F.L. on Friday suspended wide receiver Antonio Brown for eight regular-season games for his role in a January dispute with a moving company employee, for which he pleaded no contest to burglary and battery charges and received two years probation. Brown was also penalized for sending threatening texts to a woman who accused him of sexual misconduct. The suspension was first reported by The Washington Post and was confirmed in a statement by the league.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin, Alexander Burns and Katie Glueck
title: Lobbying Intensifies Among V.P. Candidates as Biden’s Search Nears an End
description: Two women, Representative Karen Bass and Susan Rice, the former national security adviser, are among the most formidable contenders on Joe Biden’s list.
content: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr. has entered the final stage of his deliberations about choosing a running mate as he prepares to talk one-on-one with the finalists next week, while Democratic leaders lobby him furiously to elevate their allies and sink their enemies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tasmiha Khan
title: How Families Are Celebrating Eid al-Adha This Year
description: You can make the festival feel special for kids, without having to leave home.
content: As the coronavirus pandemic continues to force changes to daily activities and rituals around the world, Muslim families are finding new ways to celebrate Eid al-Adha.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Are You Up on Dominic Fike Yet?’
description: The singer-songwriter-rapper’s new album, “What Could Possibly Go Wrong,” drops on Friday. Watch how he landed a multimillion-dollar record deal, a world tour and the arena-size expectations of the pop-music industry in a new Times documentary on FX and Hulu.
content: Watch on Friday, Aug. 7, at 10 p.m. on FX and streaming on Hulu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Amazon Wins Without Even Trying
description: As America’s economy suffers, Big Tech does shockingly well.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ‘Move Everything Outdoors’: Our Readers Respond
description: The coronavirus has forced many activities outside. How have Times readers adapted?
content: The Times recently asked readers to tell us about innovative ways that people were moving activities outdoors, where the coronavirus spreads less easily than it does indoors. Hundreds of people responded. The submissions were often inspiring, offering some hope that perhaps more companies, government agencies and other organizations could take similar steps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Kleon
title: The Unschooled Artists
description: Taking lessons in creativity from my kids.
content: but being home with my kids turned out to be more inspiring than any art school I can imagine. When my wife and I sent them off to school, I worried less about whether the classroom would rob them of their creativity and more about what would happen to my creativity without them around to inspire me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Sher
title: Monsters vs. Aliens
description: In “Sia Martinez and the Moonlit Beginning of Everything,” a Mexican-American girl lights candles in the desert for her deported mother. Then a spacecraft arrives.
content: Sia Martinez is trying so hard to believe in miracles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Black Is King’ and ‘Little Women’
description: A visual album from Beyoncé debuts on Disney+. And Greta Gerwig’s “Little Women” adaptation airs on Starz.
content: BLACK IS KING (2020) Stream on Disney+. This time last year, Beyoncé released “The Lion King: The Gift,” a companion album to Disney’s high-tech remake of “The Lion King” that brought together an international roster of artists including Pharrell Williams, the South African musician Moonchild Sanelly, Jay-Z, the Nigerian singer-songwriter Tiwa Savage and the Cameroonian songwriter Salatiel. Artists from that album appear alongside stars like Naomi Campbell and Lupita Nyong’o in this new visual album based on “The Gift” — a rare film based on an album that was itself based on a film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: Executives are getting together in video games, to bond, brainstorm or rampage.
description: With Zoom call fatigue setting in and boozy lunches out of the question during the coronavirus pandemic, housebound executives are finding new ways to meet and bond in video games. The goal is to break up a day that is crammed with get-togethers that generally look, sound and feel identical.
content: With Zoom call fatigue setting in and boozy lunches out of the question during the coronavirus pandemic, housebound executives are finding new ways to meet and bond in video games. The goal is to break up a day that is crammed with get-togethers that generally look, sound and feel identical.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Trump Still Defers to Putin, Even as He Dismisses U.S. Intelligence and the Allies
description: Say this about President Trump’s approach to Moscow: It’s been consistent.
content: WASHINGTON — On the eve of accepting the Republican nomination for president four years ago, Donald J. Trump declared that he would pull out of NATO if American allies did not pay more for their defense, waving away the thought that it would play into the hands of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who has spent his career trying to dismantle the Western alliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: U.K. Officials’ New Trump Dilemma: What if He Loses?
description: If Joe Biden wins the November election, Britain would face a president who opposed Brexit, would look out for Ireland, and may have little interest in a trade deal.
content: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II threw him an extravagant state banquet at Buckingham Palace. Former Prime Minister Theresa May welcomed him to Blenheim Palace, the family seat of his hero, Winston Churchill. Her successor, Boris Johnson, refused to join a global chorus of criticism after he ordered troops to break up a Black Lives Matter protest outside the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Akinmade Åkerström
title: Watching My Child Experience Racism in a Country of Contentment
description: A Black mom reflects on what it’s like raising a biracial child in Sweden, where the weeds of racism can look like green grass.
content: I sensed a looming presence next to me while I was punching away at my keyboard, hard at work. When I turned, it was to face my 8-year-old daughter standing close, her eyebrows arched inward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: A Romance Blooms in Nebraska
description: Robert Voelte and Ian Rose met at an elementary school in Omaha, where they had both taught.
content: Robert Voelte and Ian Rose call themselves an intergenerational, intercultural, interracial gay couple standing in the center of a blue dot in the middle of a red state.
